newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine stocks extend losses at close.
newsitem.headline: Argentine stocks extend losses at close.

text.p: Argentine stocks stretched losses Thursday at the close in an erratic trading pattern which traders blamed on Wall Street.
But they expected prices to stay firm Friday.

"The bolsa has latched onto the volatile streak in New York," said Gabriel Ruiz at brokers Tavelli. "Players are not shedding positions, but those who had the cash to keep buying have moved to the sidelines."
The blue-chip MerVal index fell 1.0 percent to 811.83. It had closed 0.6 percent lower Wednesday after slipping off a five-year high of 830.
Traders said next week's meeting of the U.S. Federal Reserve was sending some jitters through the markets.

"There's program selling in New York and profit-taking, which is logical after the Dow's recent upward march. There's also talk the Fed will hike rates next week, although nobody really believes that," another dealer said.
The broad market shed 0.6 percent, with losers pounding winners 43 to 16 and 22 issues closing flat.
Floor volume shrank to 27.9 million pesos from 40.8 million Wednesday, while over-the-counter turnover dwindled to 69.3 million pesos from 101.9 million Wednesday.
Main-tier losses were led by holding company Comercial del Plata, construction stock Juan Minetti and carmaker Ciadea, which fell 3.9 percent, 3.1 percent and 2.7 percent, respectively.
The top blue-chip performer was carmaker Sevel, which rebounded 3.1 percent after diving 7.0 percent Wednesday on talk of a new share issue.
Other MerVal gainers were power utility Central Costanera and gas distributor Transportadora de Gas del Sur, which rose 1.2 percent and 1.0 percent, respectively.
